items.synopsis: The Northern Territory Court of Appeal has dismissed former NT Police constable Zachary Rolfe's bid to avoid questions at the coronial inquest into the death of Kumanjayi Walker.

title.children: Court rules Zachary Rolfe must give evidence at Kumanjayi Walker inquest

image.altText: The back of a white ute, with the word "Jovi" graffitied on the back in black spraypaint.

items.synopsis: The Jon Bon Jovi Boys, or Jovi Boys, hail from a remote community of less than 200 people. Residents there say they're "terrorising" the community and they've had enough of their bad behaviour.

title.children: 'They've got no respect': Jon Bon Jovi Boys outback gang in sights of NT police

image.altText: An aerial view of Alice Springs by night.

items.synopsis: Police say the month of May was the quietest recorded in Alice Springs since 2019, allowing for some pause for officers on the ground.

title.children: Alice Springs crime rate hits four-year low during month of May

image.altText: an aerial view of a station homestead and a cattle feedlot.

items.synopsis: Helicopter charter company Top End Mustering said the highly experienced pilot was performing routine mustering when their Robinson R22 chopper crashed on Tuesday.

title.children: Pilot killed after helicopter crashes during mustering operations on remote station

image.altText: People walking in Brisbane's Queen Street Mall

items.synopsis: The latest monthly consumer price indicator shows inflation eased sharply to 5.6 per cent over the 12 months to May, down from 6.8 per cent in April. Follow our live blog for the latest updates.

title.children: Future interest rate rises uncertain as inflation hits 13-month low of 5.6pc

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Barrenjoey's chief economist Jo Masters says it all comes back to the fact inflation isn't coming down as quickly as the RBA would like for them to justify a pause in the current rate hike cycle next week — and that's because of services inflation. Here's what she said to business reporter Alicia Barry a short time ago: "The  governor's previously said that they would need to see inflation come down faster  than they expect. "If you remember  their own forecast for core  inflation in mid-2025, it is 2.9, so there is no upside room there to  absorb higher than expected  inflation, and we are seeing  services prices remain very  resilient. "You mentioned utilities, we are also seeing that in  insurance, we are seeing that in  rents, and these items were prices  almost never fall, so take a very  long time to come out of the  inflation data."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why do some economists think a rate hike is likely next Tuesday?

children.content: Barrenjoey's chief economist
Jo Masters
says it all comes back to the fact inflation isn't coming down as quickly as the RBA would like for them to justify a pause in the current rate hike cycle next week — and that's because of
services inflation
Here's what she said to
business reporter Alicia Barry
a short time ago:
"The  governor's previously said that they would need to see inflation come down faster  than they expect.

"If you remember  their own forecast for core  inflation in mid-2025, it is 2.9, so there is no upside room there to  absorb higher than expected  inflation, and we are seeing  services prices remain very  resilient.

"You mentioned utilities, we are also seeing that in  insurance, we are seeing that in  rents, and these items were prices  almost never fall, so take a very  long time to come out of the  inflation data."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to chief economist at Barrenjoey, Jo Masters, who says there are some "concerning signs" in today's inflation data. Here's what she told business reporter Alicia Barry on ABC News Channel a short time ago: "There was quite a significant base effect from fuel, but when you look at the detail, there are some concerning  signs that I think they are likely to  weigh on the minds of the RBA. "In  particular, faster than expected  rental inflation and we know that is something they are watching very, very closely. "We also saw services prices  celebrate faster than expected, and that is part of the inflation basket that is very persistent or sticky. "We  think the RBA has hikes ahead of us and we still see next week's meeting as live with an expectation that  they will hike rates."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rate hike next week still a possibility despite inflation figures

children.content: That's according to chief economist at Barrenjoey,
Jo Masters
, who says there are some "concerning signs" in today's inflation data.
Here's what she told business reporter
Alicia Barry
on
ABC News Channel
a short time ago:
"There was quite a significant base effect from fuel, but when you look at the detail, there are some concerning  signs that I think they are likely to  weigh on the minds of the RBA.
"In  particular, faster than expected  rental inflation and we know that is something they are watching very, very closely.
"We also saw services prices  celebrate faster than expected, and that is part of the inflation basket that is very persistent or sticky.
"We  think the RBA has hikes ahead of us and we still see next week's meeting as live with an expectation that  they will hike rates."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The cost of living is falling but core inflation - which strips out volatile items like petrol - remains stubbornly high. The ABS says consumer inflation rose 5.6 per cent over the year to May, down from the 6.8 per cent increase over the year to April. That's because the fuel excise was halved in April last year, so when the discount ended the rebound in petrol prices boosted inflation. The headline figure shows that prices are heading in the right direction amid 12 rises in interest rates since May last year. ABS head of price statistics Michelle Marquardt: "This month’s annual increase of 5.6 per cent is the smallest increase since April last year. " "While prices have kept rising for most goods and services, many increases were smaller than we have seen in recent months." Housing prices rose 8.4 per cent over the year, food and non alcoholic beverages rose 7.9 per cent, and furniture, household equipment and services rose 6 per cent, while petrol prices dropped 8 per cent. But Ms Marquardt notes that core inflation remains above 6 per cent as you can see from the dark line in the graph above. "It can be helpful to exclude items with volatile price changes from the headline CPI indicator to provide a view of underlying inflation,” Ms Marquardt said. “When excluding these volatile items, the decline in inflation is more modest. " "The annual increase for the monthly CPI indicator was 6.4 per cent in May, slightly lower than the rise of 6.5 per cent recorded in April and down from a peak of 7.3 per cent in December 2022." The Reserve Bank will be closely watching these figures when it considers interest rates next week.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Headline inflation pulls back

children.content: The cost of living is falling but core inflation - which strips out volatile items like petrol - remains stubbornly high.
The ABS says consumer inflation rose 5.6 per cent over the year to May, down from the 6.8 per cent increase over the year to April.
That's because the fuel excise was halved in April last year, so when the discount ended the rebound in petrol prices boosted inflation.
The headline figure shows that prices are heading in the right direction amid 12 rises in interest rates since May last year.
ABS head of price statistics Michelle Marquardt:
"This month’s annual increase of 5.6 per cent is the smallest increase since April last year. "
"While prices have kept rising for most goods and services, many increases were smaller than we have seen in recent months."

Housing prices rose 8.4 per cent over the year, food and non alcoholic beverages rose 7.9 per cent, and furniture, household equipment and services rose 6 per cent, while petrol prices dropped 8 per cent.

props.alt: graph showing headline and core inflation

children.content: Inflation eases
(ABS )
But Ms Marquardt notes that core inflation remains above 6 per cent as you can see from the dark line in the graph above.
"It can be helpful to exclude items with volatile price changes from the headline CPI indicator to provide a view of underlying inflation,” Ms Marquardt said.
“When excluding these volatile items, the decline in inflation is more modest. "
"The annual increase for the monthly CPI indicator was 6.4 per cent in May, slightly lower than the rise of 6.5 per cent recorded in April and down from a peak of 7.3 per cent in December 2022."
The Reserve Bank will be closely watching these figures when it considers interest rates next week.

image.altText: Three-year-old William Tyrrell has been missing from his NSW mid north coast home since late last week.

items.synopsis: The foster mother is maintaining she has nothing to do with William's disappearance as detectives ask the public prosecutor to consider charges relating to hiding the toddler's body.

title.children: William Tyrrell's foster mother demands to see all evidence against her after police recommend charges

image.altText: Noelene and Cedric Jordan pictured walking in a city street.

items.synopsis: If you saw them in the street you might think they seem like most older married couples — but a jury has just found them guilty of the shooting murder of their former son-in-law in 2009. So, why did it take 11 years to charge them?

title.children: The 'elimination matrix' which brought this grandfather and grandmother undone

image.altText: A black and white graphic of the two men against a Russian map with a red semi-circle behind them.

items.synopsis: Recent developments in Russia raise serious questions about the future of President Vladimir Putin and the war in Ukraine. Join our live Q&A as our experts unpack your questions.

title.children: Is Putin in trouble? Join our experts to discuss the latest struggle for power inside the Kremlin

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What is the likelihood that Ukraine will take the opportunity to invade Russia if Civil war breaks out in Russia? — David Hi David, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to global affairs editor John Lyons who says: Hello David — My view is that there is no chance that Ukraine would invade Russia. Ukraine's entire support from its international partners is predicated on defending itself from an illegal invasion. It's on that basis that various countries — many of the NATO countries, Australia and others — have provided support. For Ukraine to invade another country would mean it was doing the same thing that it was defending itself from and would lead to complete chaos in the region. I think if civil war breaks out in Russia, Ukraine will sit back and watch. Some Ukrainians may be relieved as it will mean that if the Russians are fighting internally then they will not be focused on attacking Ukraine.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What is the likelihood now of Ukraine invading Russia?

children.content: What is the likelihood that Ukraine will take the opportunity to invade Russia if Civil war breaks out in Russia? —
David
Hi David, thanks for writing in. I've put your question to global affairs editor John Lyons who says:

Hello David — My view is that there is no chance that Ukraine would invade Russia. Ukraine's entire support from its international partners is predicated on defending itself from an illegal invasion. It's on that basis that various countries — many of the NATO countries, Australia and others — have provided support.

For Ukraine to invade another country would mean it was doing the same thing that it was defending itself from and would lead to complete chaos in the region. I think if civil war breaks out in Russia, Ukraine will sit back and watch. Some Ukrainians may be relieved as it will mean that if the Russians are fighting internally then they will not be focused on attacking Ukraine.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I'd like to know why Prigozhin decided to take such a calculated risk, and why the confrontation ended so abruptly with him effectively being exiled and not charged? - Ann Thanks for writing in, Ann. I've put your question to our global affairs editor John Lyons, who says: Thanks Ann — excellent question as it cuts to the heart of the relationship now between Putin and Prigozhin. Why would Prigozhin have done it? In my assessment two reasons: he wanted to put pressure on both the Defence Minister Shoigu and Army commander Gerasimov as he believes their performance has been woeful. And secondly I think he wanted to stamp his claim to the top levels of Russian politics over coming months. Prigozhin is very ambitious, and much smarter a player than many people give him credit for. Non-one else has "stabbed" Putin in the back — Putin's own words — and got out of the country alive. And why not charged? In my view Putin was shaken, and wanted to defuse the situation asap. To charge Progozhin would have made something of a martyr out of him. Better to have in Belarus where Alexander Lukashenko can keep a very close eye on him.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why did the confrontation end so abruptly?

children.content: I'd like to know why Prigozhin decided to take such a calculated risk, and why the confrontation ended so abruptly with him effectively being exiled and not charged? -
Ann
Thanks for writing in, Ann. I've put your question to our global affairs editor
John Lyons
, who says:

Thanks Ann — excellent question as it cuts to the heart of the relationship now between Putin and Prigozhin. Why would Prigozhin have done it? In my assessment two reasons: he wanted to put pressure on both the Defence Minister Shoigu and Army commander Gerasimov as he believes their performance has been woeful.

And secondly I think he wanted to stamp his claim to the top levels of Russian politics over coming months. Prigozhin is very ambitious, and much smarter a player than many people give him credit for. Non-one else has "stabbed" Putin in the back — Putin's own words — and got out of the country alive. And why not charged? In my view Putin was shaken, and wanted to defuse the situation asap.
To charge Progozhin would have made something of a martyr out of him. Better to have in Belarus where Alexander Lukashenko can keep a very close eye on him.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Is this the first real indication of an implosion in Russia? Yevgeny Prigozhin's mutiny is the first open and armed challenge to Vladimir Putin and that's significant. Whether or not it leads to something like an implosion or further instability is unclear, but the president's position has been weakened. We now know there is at least one person bold enough and unafraid enough to publicly question Putin's authority over decisions such as who should run Russia's military and the strategy in Ukraine. This was an armed mutiny by Prigozhin, a march on Moscow, planes were shot out of the sky. It is a huge change in the dynamic inside that country. Vladimir Putin says the fact it was over within 24 hours is a sign of national unity, but power is a very delicate thing. From inside Russia, there is surprise that Yevgeny Prigozhin was even allowed to leave and wasn't met with the forces available to Putin — that he apepars to have not been punished. That will have weakened the regime. Now we should watch to see if any changes are made to the leadership of the Russian military and if any of Prigozhin's demands are met. That would be a massive victory for the man now living in exile.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is this the first real indication of an implosion in Russia?

children.content: Is this the first real indication of an implosion in Russia?
Yevgeny Prigozhin's mutiny is the

first open and armed challenge to Vladimir Putin and that's significant. Whether or not it leads to something like an implosion or further instability is unclear, but the president's position has been weakened.
We now know there is at least one person bold enough and unafraid enough to publicly question Putin's authority over decisions such as who should run Russia's military and the strategy in Ukraine.
This was an armed mutiny by Prigozhin, a march on Moscow, planes were shot out of the sky. It is a huge change in the dynamic inside that country.
Vladimir Putin says the fact it was over within 24 hours is a sign of national unity, but power is a very delicate thing.
From inside Russia, there is surprise that Yevgeny Prigozhin was even allowed to leave and wasn't met with the forces available to Putin — that he apepars to have not been punished.
That will have weakened the regime.

Now we should watch to see if any changes are made to the leadership of the Russian military and if any of Prigozhin's demands are met. That would be a massive victory for the man now living in exile.
